Comment: My first move will be the standard king's pawn opening, a favorite for most intermediate chess players.
The opponent defends the center by copying my move, so far this seems like a normal chess game.
I now attack his pawn with my knight, of course we're going to expect our oponent to defend it.
which he does, with his pawn, so far so good.
I now move up my other knight, to protect my pawn but to also add to my evil plan.
The opponent moves the b7 pawn, probably for some bishop attacks.
I move my bishop to c4, everything is in place now, let's see how my opponent reacts.
Exactly how I planned.  In his mind he made a good move because if I try to attack the bishop I'll mess up my castling side, or I could end up having a double pawn.
I make the "wrong move" and give up my queen, hoping that he takes her.
He did, like expected, and now I move in for the kill, it's mate in 2.
check, the king cannot attack the bishop because it is guarded by the knight.
the king moves to the only space available.
checkmate, the king is trapped.  This is the famous queen sacrifice/fools mate.
